intro: Prunus spinosa var. brachypetala, commonly known as the dwarf blackthorn, is a shrub native to southern Europe and western Asia. It is characterized by its thorny stems and small, dark blue to black berries that ripen in late summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 1–2 meters and features alternate, ovate leaves with serrated edges. Its flowers are white and appear in clusters, blooming before the leaves in early spring. The berries are used in traditional medicine and as a source of dye, and the plant is often found in hedgerows and woodland edges.
